job_title: Program Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: State benefits for employees are very good, including excellent healthcare options and good vacation and holiday amounts. Many positions are within a union and so there is an element of job security to some degree; the unions have been more active lately in trying to preserve benefits (such has healthcare) that may be reduced due to the state financial problems. Salaries are reasonable or even above-average, but the only raises you will get are those negotiated by your union. Those employees without union representation may never get a raise, because they do have to be awarded any raise unless it is in a union contract.
cons: The biggest downside is the culture of corruption. The may change with the new president, it is hard to say at this point in time. The second-biggest downside is incompetence; many of the employees got their jobs through political or family influence and cannot function very well. Another downside is a culture of entitlement; many employees become extremely upset when they realize that anything that is not locked up will be stolen within minutes--supplies, personal items, even food. Another downside is that because so many employees are miserable, there is an atmosphere of nastiness, depression, and frustration that is infectious.

review_title: comfortable to work, being respected, wanna stay if UMDNJ can sponsor my Green Card(US Permanent Residency)
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Newark, NJ

review_title: A great learning experience. A good place to start your career.
job_title: Research Teaching Specialist IV in Newark, NJ
pros: New Jersey Medical School, Medical School Building: The benefits are great. I worked in academic research and researchers in most labs are "jack of all trades" so you learn a lot (I was on the technician B.S. level of qualification) ... therefore you learn a lot. You will work with people from all over the world in the labs which I adored.
cons: In academic research, the resources are thin and therefore you are stretched far in terms of responsibilities. I worked long hours. There is no career ladder in their labs. You will eventually want to get into industry but it is a good place to start your career. *If you can get in* which is difficult. Jobs are scarce.

job_title: Research Teaching Specialist III in Piscataway, NJ
pros: A typical academic setting with a competitive educational/research program and associated lifestyle. Some of the research programs are top-notch, however overall the place is not "Harvard". The benefit package is quite generous. The location is good too, close to NYC and NJ shore points.
cons: The pay for research jobs is competitive at the national level, but is rather low relative to the local cost of living. The UMDNJ provides no financial aid to UMDNJ employees whose kids are entering college (well, as the majority of other educational/research institutions). IT services are not as good as those at the neighboring Rutgers University. At the moment, the UMDNJ electronic library of scientific journals lacks keys publications from the American Chemical Society.

review_title: If you want to do the same thing everyday until you retire, then this is the place for you.
pros: Great health benefits, 15 days vacation to start. Job satisfaction depends on who you work for and what you do.
cons: The culture is wrapped around defending the status quo. Most employees have worked there for a really long time (like 20 years or more), so they are not welcoming to change. Recent layoffs and salary cuts have made employees very negative and fearful. Because the staff is unionized, a lot of employees are lazy and take their job for granted. Unless you're a professor, opportunity for advancement is very limited. Most employees are just stay in the same position for years waiting to retire. If you're looking for a dynamic energetic environment, this is NOT the place for you.

pros: I love working at dental aesthetics because I was able to get to know each and every one of my patients. I was able to get my feet wet and all dental procedures from route canals to dental implants to regular feelings all the way down to fitting someone for full mouth dentures  top and bottom! I have worked many jobs from retail to a call center and I can tell you that all feel is where I belong
cons: I would say the only kind about where I work at for 2 1/2 years was the 45 minute commute around I 695

review_title: Bureaucracy that you could only find in a government-run institution.  No raise, not even cost-of-living, for over 6 yrs
pros: Matching 414a fund, decent health insurance, although the cost goes up exponentially every year.  Not much else positive to say.
cons: Just about everything else.  Terrible management, nobody cares if you live or die.  No I take that back, they do indeed want warm bodies at work.

review_title: Eulogy for a Soon to be Defunct University
job_title: Program Administrator (Director Level) in Newark, NJ
pros: On July 1, 2013, UMDNJ ceases to exist mainly due to 40 years of inept bureaucratic management, backroom political decisions and indifferent attitudes and poor work ethics of staff, faculty and administration. It will then become the problem of Rutgers University.
cons: Rutgers University appears to  possess the same ineptitude, indifference and incompetence as UMDNJ. I predict a long, difficult and costly integration process that benefits few except for the politicians that forced this merger to take place for their own self interests.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: great opportunity to contact with patients; collaborate with the hospital for clinical studies; collaborations are welcomed and encouraged here, relationships among research labs are comfortable; very convenient location, close to NYC
cons: infrastructures are dated and out of function, especially the elevators; foods are not very healthy, so you may wanna bring your own everyday, no descent restaurants nearby either; campus is too small, no gym

review_title: Registered nurse review of ICU setting

Good benefits (pension/state benefits)

Appropriate pay as compared to area 

Great learning opportunities (Level 1 Trauma Center)

Unsafe location of hospital
